titlestmt.titleproper: Sheet music collection on medical themes
Sheet music collection on medical themes
titlestmt.author: by Toby A. Appel

publicationstmt.publisher: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 9, 2019 at 03:25

did.unittitle: Sheet music collection on medical themes

repository.corpname: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

langmaterial.language: Most items are in English. There are over a 150 items in French, and some items in Spanish, German, and Dutch.

did.abstract: Sheet music on medical themes including songs and piano compositions about medical providers, ailments, remedies, health for children, and advertisements for medical products. Much of the music was performed in music halls or as part of musicals, or later, performed on radio, television, and on records.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Yale does not own copyright to this music. A majority of the items are in the public domain, but many are still under copyright.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: These materials were collected by William H. Helfand, a former pharmaceutical company executive, a historian of medicine, and a longtime collector of materials, especially prints and ephemera, related to the history of medicine.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Sheet Music Collection on Medical Themes, Historical Library, Cushing/Whitney Medical Library, Yale University, New Haven, CT

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 1 consists of sheet music in English in alphabetical order by title. Most items were published in London or in various cities in the United States, especially New York. The songs include alma maters and other music for the medical professions, humorous songs about incompetent healers and hawkers of remedies, many sentimental songs about Red Cross nurses treating wounded soldiers in World War I, songs for children to sing, songs about particular maladies (rheumatism) or remedies (cod liver oil), and popular songs that refer to physicians, chiropractors, dentists, nurses, and drug stores. Many songs from the 19th and early twentieth century were featured in music halls or as part of musicals. Portraits of performers are often featured on the cover of the sheet music. Some songs are radio theme songs. For the more recent period, there are recorded songs like Eric Clapton singing "Cocaine" or Loretta Lynn singing "The Pill," as well as theme songs from early TV shows on doctors and hospitals.

Series 2 consists of sheet music in French, arranged by size and then alphabetically. Most items were published in Paris, and most are from the 19th century or early 20th century. The lithographic cover illustrations are often by well-known printmakers. Many of the songs are part of comic scenes that contain both music and spoken words. Others are comic monologues.

Series 3 consists of a few songs in German and Dutch and several tangos from Buenos Aires, Argentina, notable for their colored cover illustrations of medical scenes and the dedication of the music to physicians.
In all these series, a number of items are incomplete and represented by an illustrated cover only, or a cover and a single page of music on the reverse.

Series 4 includes sheet music that advertises a product--usually a patent medicine--or a practitioner. Sometimes the songs or musical pieces are popular and unrelated to medicine, while other times, the words of the song directly praise the product.

Series 5 is a very large collection of sheet music published by Emerson Drug Company, Baltimore, to advertise Bromo Seltzer. These date from about 1890 to 1910. The songs themselves are popular and sentimental.

Series 6, "Miscellaneous," includes sheet music advertising St. Jacob's Oil and Beecham's Pills; song books of several musicals on doctors; books of songs published by medical schools; and songs and songbooks by publishers who took patent medicine advertisements to lower the cost of selling the music.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into six series: 1. Individual songs in English by title. 2. Individual songs in French by title, subdivided into large and small format. 3. Individual songs in other languages; Argentine tangos. 4. Music advertising a product or a practitioner. 5. Bromo-Seltzer sheet music. 6. Miscellaneous.

did.unittitle: The Evacuations, or An Emetic for Old England Glorys

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Etched broadside with a political cartoon, including a large syringe, and verses to be sung to the tune of "Derry Down." "Registered according to Act of Parliament by Mary Darley in Little Riders Court Leicesterfields." "From the Rial oak Decemr 1762." According to Stephens, a reference source cited in the Library of Congress record for this broadside: "An etched broadside, comprised in two columns of verse below a design. In the latter, Lord Bute, with an ass's head crowned with a thistle and a peacock's feather, stands on a mountebank's stage and blows bubbles towards a mob of men who follow him..." Dated by Stephens November 3, 1762 or after.

scopecontent.p: Composed by E. Carpentier De Selvier. Exeter: Published by the author, n.d. (19th cent.). "The profit derived from these waltzes is for the benefit of Devon & Exeter Hospital."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Gertrude Gore, music by Olive Dungan. New York: G. Ricordi & Co., c. 1952. From "Eight Character Studies for Young Folks." Song for children on eating healthy foods.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Composed by Ch. Schuster. Boston: Oliver Ditson, n.d. (mid 19th cent.). "Composed and respectfully dedicated to Drs. Wesselhoeft & Felerer."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by A. J. Mills, music by Bennett Scott. London: B. Feldman, n.d. (19th cent.). Sung by George Robey. Humorous song with one verse on medicine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Willis N. Bugbee, music by Thos. B. Weaver. Syracuse, N.Y.: The Willis N. Bugbee Co., c. 1920. A song for children to sing. Includes motions to be made by the children.

did.unittitle: We've Had a Lovely Time, So Long, Good Bye

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Blanche Merrill, music by Leo Edwards. New York: Chas. K. Harris, c. 1912. From "The Trained Nurses." This song doesn't have medical content.

did.unittitle: What the Doctor Ordered (Or Everything Done Browne): Humorous Ballad on the New Food Regulations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words an music by Sylvester Gaffney. Dublin: Walton's Piano and Musical Instrument Galleries, c. 1951. On the nuisances of complying with the new food handling regulations.

did.unittitle: When a Man's a Little Bit Poorly

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by T. Hudson, music by J. Blewitt. London: T. E. Pudy, n.d. (early to mid 19th cent.). The doctor's successive treatments make him feel worse; he gets better when he gives up all "physic."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Willlis N. Bugbee, music by Thos. B. Weaver. Copyright 1921 by Willis N. Bugbee. A sticker for Baker's Plays, Boston, has been pasted over original publisher name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Lida Keck-Wiggins, music by Thos. B. Weaver. Copyright 1923 by L. M. Paine. A sticker for Baker's Plays, Boston has been pasted over the original publisher name. Song for children with directions for staging.

did.unittitle: Why Winnie Went to War to Be a Nurse

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words and music by Joseph McManus, Jr. Published by the McManus Publishing Company, Los Angeles, 1915. World War I nursing. Puchased 2017 and added to the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words and music by Jim Stafford and Don Bowman. Copyright 1964 by Famous Music Corporation, Boo Music and Parody Publishing Co. Recorded by Jim Stafford on MGM Records. On hallucinogenic weeds on the farm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Ross Bagdasarian. Chicago: Monarch Music Co., c. 1958. Recorded by David Seville on Liberty records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

"Composed for and played by The Yeast Foamers Novelty Orchestra on the Northwestern Yeast Company Radio Programs through the National Broadcasting Company Network." Advertisements for "The Yeast Foam Family" on the back cover.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words and music by Charles Osborne, arranged by Henry E. Pether. London: Francis, Day & Hunter, c. 1897 in USA. Sung by Harry Randall. Two verses on germs and medicines.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: You Can't Make Love With A Cold

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words and music by Gene Crowley. London: Peter Maurice Music Co., Ltd, c. 1951. Recorded by Phil Harris. His romantic life is spoiled by sneezing, coughing, the flu, and hay fever.

did.unittitle: You'll Never Need a Doctor No More

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Chris Smith. New York: Skidmore Music Co., c. 1921. Sung by Bert Williams in "Broadway Brevities." Blackface characters on cover.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Bert Brown. Troy, N.Y.: Koninsky Music Co., c. 1918. Cover shows a child in a Red Cross uniform and a boy dressed as a soldier. If needed, they will fight in the future like their parents did in World War I.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words and music by Leo Robin and Ralph Rainger. New York: Paramount Music Corporation, c. 1938. From "Paris Honeymoon," a Paramount Picture, with Bing Crosby.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Andrew B. Sterling, music by Felix Bernard. New York: Tell Taylor, c. 1915. The doctor tells the young woman to stop dancing all evening.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words and music by John J. Schneider. Philadelphia: Songtext Music Company, c. 1934. "Fox Trot Novelty Song."

did.unittitle: Individual Songs in French by title

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Many of the French songs are comic pieces performed at theaters in Paris including the Eldorado, the Alcazar, the Amabassadeurs, and La Scala. Many items contain both spoken words and music. Some are monologues, either with music for the entry and exit of the performer, or no music at all. A number of the songs feature the clyster, a huge enema syringe, or its updated version the "Clyso" pump.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are a few small-format songs in this subseries. The arrangement of the collector was maintained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Th. Aillaud, music by Flix Chaudoir. This item is a leaf from a issue of Paris qui Chante, published by Chavat and Girier, Paris, July 22, 1903. Paris qui Chantewas published weekly beginning in 1903. Sung by Max Morel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Title page only. No music. Composed by Alph[on]se Longueville. Paris: Mnestrel, n.d. (19th cent.).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by "GIL," music by F. Boissire. Printed by Delanchy, n.d. (19th cent.). Cover has been trimmed, although the music is complete.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Faure (?). Song published in Le Potard Enchain, humor supplement toLa Gazette des Pharmacies, Paris, August 1921. The four pages of the issue contain articles and cartoons about pharmacists and pharmacies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by J. C. Massoulier, music by M. Blanchot. Paris: Editions musicales Septentrion, c. 1966. Sung by les Freres Jacques.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cover page only. By Araban. Comic opera by E. Gautier. Paris: E. Grard et Cie., n.d. (19th cent.).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These items -- sheet music and comic monologues -- were formerly housed in looseleaf notebooks separate from the songs in the previous subseries. Sizes vary but all fit into 28.5 x 22 cm sleeves. Most date from the late 19th to the early 20th century. There are some small-format songs in the large-format subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Recitation. Words by Jean Lygo and Jacques Francis. Paris: Editions Lyjo, c. 1934. Performed by Lyjo, Jacques Francis, and others. 1934 was the year of Marie Curie's death.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Arthur Canu and Henri Canu, music by Ch. Niepce de St Victor. Paris: L. Colas, Editeur, n.d. Performed by Debailleul at the XIXe Sicle, by Sarius at La Scala, by Sautereau at the Orphum, and by Mme. Delacroix at the Gait Montparnasse.

did.unittitle: L'Ambulancire, ou soldats, cessez le feu - romance patriotique

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Emile Andr, music by Robert Planquette. Paris: L. Bathlot-Joubert Editeurs, n.d. Cover shows a woman rubbing the unclothed back of a man.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Eugne Rimbault, music by Emile Spencer. Paris: Repertoire Polin, n.d. Performed by Polin at La Scala. Cover shows an officer looking at a naked recruit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Hector Barreyre, music by S. S. Nannelli. Paris: La Parisienne, Edition Musicale, n.d. Performed by Cadex at the Europen. Also sung by Danvers, Max Lucian, Berki, Duc Paul, Romanet, Doubl, and others.

did.unittitle: La Belle Bourbonnaise/ La Nouvelle Bourbonnaise

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Music arranged by M. H. Colet. Drawings by M. Trimolet, engravings by Couch and Torlet. No information on publication. Mid-19th century.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Francine and Xavier Privas. Song appears to be extracted from Nos Chansons Franaises, no year, pp. 240-241.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By G. Choquet de Broca. No publication information. Extracted from a songbook.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: a vaut mieux...que attraper la scarlatine

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Andr Hornez, music by Paul Misraki. Copyright 1936 by Ray Ventura & Cie. & Royalty, Paris. "One Step de l'Oprette 'Normandie'."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by R. de St. Prest and L. Christian, music by Albert Petit. Paris: A. Queille, Editeur-Compositeur, n.d. Image of a comic man, and off to his side is a hand pointing a clyster at him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Ren Bastien, music by D. Grimonpont. Extract from Nos Chansons Franaises, No. 108, 1929. Incomplete.

did.unittitle: Le Charlatan, ou le remde universel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Mr. Paulin, music by Charles Plantade. Paris: Frey, Editeur, n.d. (early 19th century). Lithograph on cover of a man in Napoleonic costume standing in a carriage and promoting a remedy. Three musicians in the carriage are playing and a crowd gathers round.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by E. Hubert, music by F. Boissire. Paris: Fouquet, Editeur, n.d. (19th cent.). Lithograph of a man standing on a table and promoting a bottle to a crowd. Behind him is a drum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by E. Barlie, music by L. Godefroy. Paris: Smyth, Editeur, n.d. (early 20th cent.). Music and spoken words.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Baltha and L. Guetteville, music by L. Gueteville. Paris: Repertoire Gueteville, Plbins, Editeur. This is a comic scene with spoken words as well as song. Performed by Pascal at the Concert Parisien, and by Chambot at the Eldorado. Accompanied by a separate brochure with the words to the scene as performed by Chambot. The cover image shows an Arab wearing a tassled hat and holding out a remedy in a bottle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Bach and Henry-Laverne. Paris: E. Bousquet, Editeur, n.d. (20th cent.). Recorded on Odon records. This a comic scene with words and no music. Henry-Laverne plays the pharmacist and Bach the client.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Bach and Henry-Laverne. Another version of the above comic scene, published in Receuil de cinq dialogues et scnes comiques clebres cres et enregistrs sur disques "Odeon" par Bach et Henri-Laverne. Paris: Les Editions Jean Picot, Ex-Editions Sait Gilles, n.d. (early 20th cent.).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Monologue by Eugne Wyl, in Recueil de dix monologues et chansons loufoques cres par Pierre Dac. No. 51 Paris: Les Editions Jean Picot, Ex-Editions Saint-Gilles, n.d. [early 20th century].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Disle, music by A. Teste. Paris: Emile Benoit, Editeur, n.d. (19th cent.). Color image of a grandmother suddenly struck with an ailment while at a dining table with her family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words and music by E. Bousquat, Ch. Gonzalez and M. Labastrou. Paris: A la Chanson Moderne, n.d. Image of a pump-like device identified by the next item as a "clysopompe," a modern version of the clyster.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Monologue by Mac-Nab. Extract from Pomes incongrus by Lon Vanier. In Les Chansons illustres, No. 18, n.d. Perfomed by Mac-Nab. Image of the pump.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Monologue by Xanrof. From Les Chansons Illustres, No. 86, 2e srie (No. 142 de la Collection), Libraire Contemporaine, Paris, n.d. (20th cent.). Entire issue.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Briollet-Alain, music by H. Christin. Paris: M. Labb, Editeur, n.d. (early 20th cent.). Music and spoken words. Performed by Dranem at the Eldorado and by Ren Raoult at the Petit Casino.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Lon Maillot. Verses but no music. Paris: A. Fouquet, Editeur, n.d. Performed by Riviore at the Horloge. On the Catholic clergy which become crows as they head toward Rome. The complicated image includes a man with a clyster as a weapon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Eug Rimbault, music by P. Codini. Extracted from an unidentified source. Performed by Polin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by A. Isch Wall, music by Emile Duhem. Paris: O Bornemann, n.d. Comic dialogue with some music about a quarrel between two doctors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Plbus and Rodor, music by Fernand Heintz. Paris: "Ancienne Maison Guprotte & Bloch - Madame Ccile Gilbert, Successeur," n.d. (20th cent.). From "Edition Musicale 'Au Point d'Orgue'." A monologue performed by Constantin as the "doctor."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Joseph Kelm, music by Vicomte de Flaboss. Paris: Marcel Labb, Editeur, n.d. Performed by Joseph Kelm as a charlatan promoting a remedy. There is an earlier version of this song in the large format French songs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Maader and Dupuy, music by Guteville and Maader. Originally published by Guteville, Paris. From Les Chansons et Monologues Illustres, No. 471, n.d. Words only.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Yody, music by L. Demortreux. Paris: A La Gamme, n.d. (late 19th cent.). In the color image, an attractive woman doctor feels the pulse of a gentleman. There is a fetus in a bottle on the table.

did.unittitle: Le Doigt de pied de Saint Guignolet: monologue comique

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Monologue by Delormel and Garnier. Paris: Eveillard et Jacquot, Editeurs, n.d. Performed by Rval at La Scala. Cover image of patients showing an ailing part of their bodies to the toes of a statue of a Catholic saint.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Jean Bonin, music by Emile Duhem, Paris: Emile Benoit, Editeur, n.d. Color image of men and women promenading in the street.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Jehan Madelaine, music by F. Matz Ferrare. One leaf may be incomplete. No publication information. Dedicated to Lucien Lagane, "Pharmacien a Bordeaux." Performed by A. Guillemot of the Grand-Thatre de Bordeuax. Image of a bottle, words indistinct, and men drinking and hanging up their crutches. Elixir Lagane appears to be a fictional cure-all.

did.unittitle: Elle avait un p'tit cad'nas!: chanson d'actualit

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Valentin Pannetier and Marcel Dsauts. Paris: V. Pannetier, Editeur, n.d. Words only. Cover image of a Satanic figure unlocking a lock around the waist, wrists, and genitals of a naked woman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Henry Moreau and Plbus, music by Vincent Scotto. Paris: Marcel Labb, Editeur, n.d. (20th cent.) First performed by Alibert. Cover lists many others who have performed the piece.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words only to be sung to the tune of "C'tait une fille" by Gabaroche. Words by Gabriello. Paris: The author, n.d. Performed by the author at the "Cabaret des Quat' z' Arts." List of several other performers and theaters. The "embryoscope" is an imaginary instrument which determines if the fetus is a boy or a girl.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One leaf only. Incomplete. Words by Martial Vergnolle, music by Barret. Paris: Pitau, Editeur, n.d. Cover image of a man administering a clyster to a patient in a military hospital bed. Performed by Sulbac at the Eldorado, and by St. Bonnet.

did.unittitle: Etude sur le corps: scne comique

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words only. Single leaf. Words and music by Saint-Gilles and Briollet. No publication information. On the human body.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by E. Favart, music by P. Codini. Paris: Aux Editions L. Codini, F. Galifer, & Julsam, n.d. Cover image of a Red Cross nurse tending a soldier on the battlefield

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words only. Words by Valentin Pannetier and Marcel Hamel, music by Vincent Scotto. Paris: Valentin Pannetier, Editeur, n.d. (20th cent.) 606 refers to Paul Ehrlich's treatment for syphilis. Image of a man before and after the inoculation. List of various performers and theaters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Mortreuil and Joullot, music by Helmer. Paris: Marcel Labb, Editeur, n.d. Performed by Brard at the Eldorado, and others at various theaters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Victor Gresset, music by Constant Dhorn. From Le Cri-Cri: Revue bi-mensuelle de la chanson franaise, Paris, n.d.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by E. Gitral and J. Bertet, music by Vincent Scotto. Paris: Vincent Scotto, Compositeur Editeur, c. 1924. Performed by Alibert at the Olympia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by C. Collet and E. Gibert, music by Laurent Halet. Paris: Laurent Halet, n.d. Recorded by Constantin on various record labels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Emile Cheret, music by Ed. Deconclois. Paris: F. Bigot, Editeur, n.d. Song in praise of Louis Pasteur. Performed by Marius Richard at la Scala. Image of Pasteur and various scenes related to him on the cover, and a banner with the label "Institut Pasteur."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words and music by L. Benech and E. Dumont. Copyright L. Benech, Paris, 1913. Performed by Dona. Cover image is of a doctor and nurse at the hospital bedside of a young girl.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words and music by Emile Duhem. Originally Published by S. Patay, Paris. Words only. Single sheet probably extracted from a contemporary magazine on French songs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Saint-Gilles and Briolet, music by Saint Gilles. Words only. From Recueil de douze monologues et scnes comiques, No. 6, pp. 5-6. Paris: Les Editions Jean Picot, n.d. (20th cent.). Song refers to inoculation with glandular extracts for rejuvenation. Another medically themed song in the issue is "A bas les lgumes" by Saint-Gilles and P. Briollet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by A. Gremillet (called Gervy), music by P. Codini. Paris: P. Codini, Compositeur-Editeur, c. 1916. Performed by Vorelli. Cover image of a Red Cross nurse in a heart-shaped frame.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Plbius and Mauban, music by Emile Spencer. Paris: G. Sivier, Editeur, n.d. Performed by Chevailier at the Cigale, and by others at other theaters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Louis Chautard, music by Alfred Sguin. Paris: Louis Aerts, Editeur, n.d. Performed by Marcel Montel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Villemer and Delormel, music by Ch. Pourny. Paris: S. Bornemann, Editeur, n.d. Performed by Victorin at the Eldorado. Cover has several images including a man being chased by a flying clyster.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Go Koger, music by Vincent Scotto and Ouvrard. Paris: E. Bousquet, Editeur, c. 1932. Performed by Ouvrard. Music and patter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Serge Lama, music by Alice Doma. Paris: Plein Soleil and Bagatelle Editions Musicales, c. 1971. Recorded by Sergh Lama on Disques Philips.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Maubon and Haldy, music by E. Spencer. Prais: Bertal-Maubon, c. 1912. "Rpertoire Bertal-Maubon." Performed by Montel at the Eldorado.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by A. Isch Wall, music by Gustave Chaillier. Paris: Bathlot, Editeur, n.d. (19th cent.) Sung by Gustave Chaillier at the Eldorado. Cover image of a servant bringing a clyster to a wealthy man wearing a robe and slippers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Spoken words, no music. Words by Jean Pheu and Denola. Paris: L. Maurel (M.D.), Editeur, n.d. Performed by Darius M. at the Parisiana, and by various other performers at other theaters.

did.unittitle: J les!!!, ou les tapes amoureuses d'un gommeux pharmacien

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Jules Dumont, music by Edmond Potier. Paris: J. Dumont, Editeur, n.d. Song and spoken words performed by Mme. Mandarine at the Ambassadeurs.

did.unittitle: Le Lavement au bouillon gras, ou la peur d'tre cocu

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Recitation, no music. Paris: Bassereau, Editeur, n.d. Performed by Villemer. Color lithograph on cover of a boy and an older woman exchanging a huge clyster.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Belhiatus and Rimbault, music by Emile Spencer. Paris: Delormel & Cie, Editeurs, n.d. (early 20th cent.).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by JAN, Music by JIL. Copyright 1959 by Les Nouvelles Editions Meridian, Paris, and Southern Music, Brussels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by V. Scotto and Gitral, music by Vincent Scotto. Paris: Dufrenne, Editeur, n.d. (early 20th cent.). "Repertoire Mayol."

did.unittitle: Le Malade et le mdecin: duo comique

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Ches. Voizo, music by B. Vallet. No indication of publisher. Dated in pencil 1838. Cover lithograph of a doctor at the home of a male patient.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Monologue by G. Brandimbourg. Paris: Vve. Lon Hayard, n.d. Cover image of a Major and sick Zouave.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Monologue by Marcel Contandin. Paris: E. Bosuquet, n.d. Performed by Fernand Sined and by a list of others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Monologue by Emile Carr. Paris: Eveillard and Jacquot, Editeurs, n.d. Printed text edited in pencil in French. Performed by Libert at la Scala and by Rgiane at the Eden-Concert. Various scenes on the cover including a man using a big clyster as a weapon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Saint-Gilles and Briolet, music by Saint-Gilles. Single sheet, probably extracted from a magazine, with words only. No publication information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Monologue by Deroyre. Paris: Editions Francis Salabert, n.d,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Louis Bousquet, music by L. Izoird. From Nos Chansons Franaises, No. 96, September 1928, pp. 238-239. Performed By Dalbret.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by A. Trbitsch and V. Tarault, music by Fl. Vargues. Paris: Georges Ondet, Editeur, n.d. (early 20th cent.). "Repertoire Resse." Sung by Mme. Debernay at the Ambassadeurs and by Resse at the Parisiana.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Abron de Cangogis (Baron de Sigognac). Paris: Ple-Mle-Edition, n.d. Series "Monologues pour Jeunes Gens," No. 7.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Eugne Lemercier, music by Roger Berville. Extract from Nos Chansons Franaises, No. 136, January 1932, pp. 15-16.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Gerny and Briollet, music by A. Gramet and Briollet. Paris: Emile Benoit, Editeur, n.d. (early 20th cent.). Performed by Vaunel at the Alhambra. List of other performers and theaters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Edouard Guy, music by Paul Leconte. Paris: M. Labb, Editeur, n.d. Performed by Charlus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Lucien Delormel, music by Flicien Vargues. Paris: G. Ondet, n.d. Performed by Yvette Guilbert at the Concert Parisien, and by Mlle. Anna Thibaud at la Scala. Color lithograph image of a young pharmacist and a young woman in a pharmacy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Saint-Gilles and Doumel. From Recueil de Douze Monologues, No. 18. This issue is titles "Histoires & blagues Marseillaises cres par Doumel." Paris: Les Editions Jean Picot, n.d. (early 20th cent.). Other monologues in this issue with medical themes include "Chez le Docteur Voronoff" (on glandular transplants for rejuvenation), and "Parisiens et Marseillais."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cover and first page of music only. Words by Vyl and Plibus, music by Edouard Jouve. Paris: Edouard Jouve, Editeur, n.d. "Rpertoire Gaudet." Performed by Mlle. Gaudet at the Eldorado. List of other performers and theaters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Mme A. Blanc-Pridier, music by Mme. J. Fonssagrives. Extracted from Nos Chansons Franaises, No. 72, September 1926, pp. 234-235. Song about a sick doll.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Pousigue-Meyrel, music by Hugh-Cannon. Paris: Smyth, Editeur, c. 1901. "Chanson sur les motifs de I Hates to Get Up Early in the Morn."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Monologue by Abron de Cangogis (Baron de Sigognac). Paris: Ple-Mle-Edition, n.d. From series "Monologues pour jeunes gens."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words and music by Roggees. Paris: Baudot, Editeur, n.d. (19th cent.). Performed by Paulus at la Scala. Chromolithograph of a photographer adjusting a camera on a tripod, while the subject, a young woman, can't stand still because she has an itch (a flea).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By F. De Flotow. Paris: C. Joubert, n.d. From the series "Lyre Franaise."

did.unittitle: L'Opration du Saint-Esprit: monologue comique en vers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Latapie. Paris: H. Billy, Successeur de L. Baudot, n.d.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Bin. Lebreton and F. Desplantes, music by J. Arnauld. Paris: Emile Benoit, Editeur, n.d. (19th cent.). Cover lithograph of a young man and a young woman. The woman holds a "Clyso" pump.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Victor Vallier. Paris: Editions Herpin, n.d. Words with indication of tunes to be played. Performed by Victor Vallier at the Noctambules and by Marcel Saget at the Petit Casino and the Europen. About the advertisements for products, including medical products, that the one can while riding on a train.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Lo Lelivre and Fernand Dervyl, music by Alcib Mario and Naudin-W. Paris: Charles Mayol, c. 1908. "Rpertoire Flix Mayol." Performed by Mayol at the Ambassadeurs.

did.unittitle: Le Pharmacien occup: scne comique a deux personages

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Belhiatus, music by Hermand-Brun. Paris: Emile Benoit, n.d. Piano music for entry and exit, and spoken dialogue. Performed by M.M. Chavat and Girier at la Scala. Cover image of a wealthy man at a pharmacist's counter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Belhiatus, music by Hermand-Brun. Words only, extracted from Les Chansons Illustres, 2e srie, No. 8. Performed by Chavat and Girier at la Scala.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Hector Sombre, music by Gaston Maquis. In Le Rve du Chanteur, No. 46, n.d. Honor Pion, Imprimeur-Editeur.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Delormel and Garnier. Paris: Rpertoire moderne, n.d. Music for entry and exit and words for a monologue. Cover lithograph of of a wealthy older man seated and another man standing, perhaps offering a pill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Monologue with words by Sim. Paris: Marcel Labb, n.c. (20th cent.). Performed by Charlus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Villemar-Delormel, Music by Ch. Pourney. Paris: Emile Benoit, Editeur, n.d. Performed by Mr. Garnier at the Alcazar and by Mr. Sulbac at the Ambassadeurs. Sheet music torn but not affecting words or music. Lithograph cover of the Commandant and a subordinate. The "pipe" is a "Clyso" pump.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Garofolo and Grinda, music by P. Codini. Marseilles: Andr Cidale, Editeur, n.d. Sold by Labb in Paris. Performed by Grinda at the Ambassadeurs and Sardou at the Alcazar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words and music by Jean de Kerlecq. From La Bonne Chanson, 5e anne, no. 51, January 1912, pp. 12-13.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Paul Lorans. Paris: J. Ferrand, Editeur, n.d.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Lon Stoll, music by R. Pandra. Paris: Editions Marcus, n.d. (20th cent.). "Causerie radiophonique de Stoll." Music and monologue. Image of a professor pointing at a skeleton.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Rimbault, music by Christin. Paris: P. H. Christin, n.d. (20th cent.). Performed by Polin at la Scala. About a woman pharmacist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by L. Marcel, music by Jules Lacoustne. Paris: G. Ondet, Editeur, n.d. Performed by Velly at the Eldorado. Cover image of a man and woman in bed accosted by a huge flea.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Chicot, music by M. Peyrla. Paris: Emile Benoit, n.d.(early 20th cent.). Performed by Vaunel and Constantin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Monologue by Georges Goudon. Lyon: Max Orgeret, Editeur, n.d. [early 20th cent.]. Image of a huckster promoting a bottled remedy to a group of people.

did.unittitle: Le Renard du Sacr-Coeur: lgend fin de sicle

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by A. Poupay, music by Emile Spencer. Paris: Albert Repos, n.d. (ca. 1900). Performed by Sulbac at the Eldorado. Colored image of a fox surrounded by a group of people in a church. Some, including a general and a clergyman, are attacking the fox. One man is using a clyster as a weapon. A young woman is holding holding up her skirt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Henri Min, music by Ch. Sebye. Paris: Emile Benoit, Editeur, n.d. Performed by Jules Hervier at the winter Alcazar, and by Guichard at the summer Alcazar. Image of a man and a woman walking away from a pharmacy shop, but not touching or looking at each other.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Eugne Lemercier. Paris: Marcel Labb, Editeur, n.d. When the doctor bends over the patient in bed, his hairpiece attaches to a cone ("cornet') glued with a substance to catch insects. The toup flies off the doctor's bald head and the patient is cured by laughter. Image of this scene on the cover.

did.unittitle: Les Saints de Paris: ou le calendrier fin de sicle

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by V. Damien, music by A. Vieillot. Paris: F. Bigot, Editeur, n.d. (ca. 1900). Performed by Caudieux at the Petit-Casino. One Saint is Saint Clyso, with reference to the "Clsyo" (clyster) pump. Another is Saint Corset. Color lithograph on cover illustrating all the "Saints."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Briollet and Gerny, music by Del-Fragson. Paris: Rpertoire Franais, n.d. (early 20th cent.). Performed by Fragson at the summer Alcazar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Emile Andr and T. Bruet, music by A. Guyon fils [Guyon, Jr.]. Paris: Bathlot-Joubert, Editeurs, n.d. Color lithograph cover showing an apothecary in love holding a huge clyster.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by E. Rayel and A. Moullet, music by L. Lust. Paris: F. Bigot, Editeur, n.d. Performed by E. C. Luciani at the Concert Parisien and by Louis Chevalier at the Moulin-Rouge. Color image shows a young pharmacist holding a clyster and serenading a woman on a balcony. The woman throws the contents of a chamberpot at him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: French words by Richard Anthony, English version by Norman, McGear, and McGouch. London: Noel Gay Music Co., Ltd, c. 1968. S.A.C.E.M., Belgium, has French and Belgian rights. This item is the French version. The Sirop Typhon is a panacea. Cover image of a strong man flexing his muscles, with a waiter bringing him Syrop Typhon. Recorded on Tacoun records and distributed by Path-Marconi.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by R. Devilliers, music by Georges Briez. Paris: Publications Raoul Breton & Cie, c. 1933. Performed by Ren Devilliers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Edmond Goupil, music by Auguste Olivier. Paris: F. Gauvin, Editeur, n.d. Performed by Jules Lter at the Eldorado. Cover image of a Vesalius-like bearded man contemplating a skull set on top of Renaissance-era books. A scale and alchemical apparatus are also in the room.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Jules Jouy to be sung to the tune, "Le Temps des cerises." Extracted from La Bonne Chanson, No. 41, March 1911, p. 87

did.unittitle: Totor et Plon-Plon: chanson de circonstance

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words and music by "M***." Paris: Tralin, Editeur de Musique, n.d. (19th cent.). Humorous song about the Emperor vs. the French Republic. Cover image of a Napoleonic soldier carrying a clyster and with a chamberpot draped from his neck down his back. He is conversing with a man in the form of a bee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Trimmed cover only. Words by Jules Combe, music by Eug. Gavel. No information on publication. Advertisement on back for music published by Bloch et Valsien, successors to E. Guprotte, Paris. "Rpertoire Bach."

did.unittitle: Les Tyroliennes de la vie: Scne comique imitative

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Blondelet and Baumaine, music by Charles Malo. Paris: Feuchot, Editeur, n.d. Verses about the life of a man at 20, 40, and 60. Lithograph cover illustrating scenes from the song and spoken verses. Performed by Mr. Bruet at the Eldorado and by Mr. Desroches at the summer Alcazar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Eugne Hanappier, music by F. Masini. Paris: J. Delahante, Editeur de Musique, n.d. (early-mid 19th cent.). Lithograph cover showing a daughter kneeling at the bed of her dying father.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Gaston Secrtan. From La Bonne Chanson, 4e anne, No. 66, August 1911, pp. 234-235. On water treatments at a spa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Monologue by Ren Esse and Gerny. From Les Chansons Illustres, No. 14, n.d. Originally published by E. Benoit. Performed by Vaunel at the Eldorado.

did.unittitle: Vous vous plaignez Franois, vous avez tort

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by E. Gerny and Reyar, music by Emile Duhem. Paris: Emile Benoit, Editeur, n.d. (19th cent.). Performed by Arnaud at the Eden-Concert. Cover image of a man (presumably the singer) dressed as a matron. Smaller images including one of a woman attacking a man with a clyster.

did.unittitle: Y a qu' des microbes!..: monologue comique

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Lo Lelivre and J. Mathis, music by G. Burgairolles. Paris: E. Lacroix, Editeur, n.d. (20th cent.). Words only. Performed by Dranem at the Eldorado.

did.unittitle: Individual songs in other languages; Argentine tangos
El 606: tango medicinal para la curacin de todo mal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Composed by Reynaldo Sales de Araujo. Buenos Aires: Alfred O. Francalanci, n.d. (early 20th cent.). "Dedicado los boticarios." Image of a doctor injecting a patient. 606 refers to physician Paul Ehrlich's 606th trial, which resulted in Salvarsan, a remedy for syphilis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Eduardo Aroley. "Dedicado a los distinguidos Doctor Ricardo Rodriguez Villegas y Moises Benchetrit." Buenos Aires: Breyer Hnos., n.d. (early 20th cent.).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Vicente Greco. "Dedicato a los practicantes Internos de los Hospitales de la Capital, con motivo del tercer Baile del Internado, 21 Septiembre de 1916." Buenos Aires: Breyer Hnos., ca. 1916.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Fritz Kochinsky. Wilhelmshaven: Otto Heinrich Noetzel, c. 1957. For three male voices and piano.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Composed by Fritz Koschinsky. Wilhelshaven, Germany: Otto Heinrich Noetzel, c. 1958. For three male voices and chamber orchestra. Full score.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By Aleardo Battisti. Buenos Aires: Breyer Hermanos, n.d. (early 20th cent.). "Al Distinguido Medico y Amigo Dr Enrique Feinmann."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Emerson Drug Company, Baltimore, Maryland, first produced Bromo-Seltzer in 1888. It was marketed as a remedy for headache and neuralgia, and also for insomnia, nervousness, hangover or depression following alcoholic excess, nervous dyspepsia, and stomach disorders. Early advertisements noted that it contained no cocaine and no morphine.

From the 1890s to the 1910s, the company produced collections of popular sheet music with piano and organ accompaniment. Many of the songs were sentimental or patriotic. The front and back covers of the music contained advertisements for Bromo-Seltzer. The music was distributed for free by druggists all over the United States, many of whose names are stamped on the cover page of the music, or the pieces could be obtained from the Music Department of the Emerson Drug Company by enclosing a stamp and a Bromo-Seltzer wrapper.
Most items do not have copyright dates. The most recent copyright date is 1900. A number of pieces are by Philadelphia composer George M. Vickers or copyrighted by Vickers.
There are several series:

(1) Individual titles, not part of a collection. For one of these, "Murphy's Head," the words of the song directly advertised Bromo-Seltzer as a remedy for hangovers. These appear to date from 1890 to 1892.

(2) Emerson Drug Co., The Bromo-Seltzer Collection of 54 Popular Songs, Complete and Unabridged. Full music Size with Piano and Organ Accompaniment. The cover image is of a woman playing a Chickering piano. This edition predates the next and the song sheets date from 1890-1892.

(3) Emerson Drug Co., The Bromo-Seltzer Collection of 74 Popular Songs, Complete and Unabridged, Full Music Size with Piano and Organ Accompaniment. Some songs include testimonials from 1892 and others have testimonials from 1895. A few have "New Selections, Added January 1st 1898. A very few mention the forthcoming Columbian Exposition of 1893. The date range is therefore ca. 1892-1898. The cover image is of a woman playing a Stieff Piano.

(4) Emerson Drug Co., The Bromo-Seltzer Collection of 83 Popular Songs, Complete & Unabridged with Piano & Organ Accompaniment. Version 1, with red and blue print, lists "New Selections Added, January 1st, 1899." These songs may have a page of testimonials dated 1895. The second version, black and white, which should be slightly later, lists the same songs as "New Selections Added." The date is ca. 1899.

(5) Emerson Drug. Co., Bromo-Seltzer Edition of 171 Popular Selections, Complete and Unabridged with Piano & Organ Accompaniment. There are two versions. Version 1 shows a woman blowing a horn with her arm around a giant Bromo-Seltzer bottle. Version 2 has a decorative design that incorporates musical instruments and sheet music. These editions of 171 selections are more recent than the previous 83 popular songs and from the images are likely to date between 1900 and 1910.

(6) Emerson Drug Co., The Bromo-Seltzer New Edition: 52 Popular Selections, Complete & Unabridged with Piano & Organ Accompaniment.This edition presumes that there is a complete list of 171 selections. It is also likely to date from 1900 to 1910.

(7) "Edition De Luxe." These have cover pages in color and were copyrighted by Will Wood. The De Luxe Music Co., New York, was the sole selling agent. None are dated. This sheet music no longer advertised Bromo-Seltzer on the front cover nor had the names of pharmacies printed on them. They were distributed "Compliments of Emerson Drug. Co." Advertisements appear on the bottom of pages of music and on the back cover. They date from ca. 1910. De Luxe Music Co. probably made similar arrangements to print music with advertisements for other companies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: St. Jacobs Oil was manufactured as far back as 1870 by the Charles A. Vogeler Company, Baltimore, Maryland, as a remedy for pain. The company published the "St Jacobs Oil Series of Music" similar to the Bromo-Seltzer sheet music. There is considerable overlap among titles. The sheet music also contains advertisements for Diamond Vera-Cura, a remedy for dyspepsia. As in the case of Bromo-Seltzer the music could be obtained in drug stores or by writing to the company, and enclosing a stamp and a product wrapper. The most recent pieces of sheet music (ca. 1905) were published by St. Jacobs Oil, Ltd, Baltimore.

did.unittitle: Beecham's Music Portfolio advertizing Beecham's Pills

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Beecham's pills were advertized to women for "bilious and nervous disorders" and a variety of other ailments.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These small format (20 cm.) booklets of popular music were published by Thomas Beecham, Proprietor of Beecham's Pills, St. Helens, Lancashire. The collection includes volumes 1-3, 5 -6, 11-18, 20. There is also a revised volume 2. Each volume contained 30 pieces numbered from 1 to 600. They could be purchased from the company.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection also contains individual songs from the 20 volumes in the same small format. They were given away by drug stores and date from the turn of the 20th century. The collection contains numbers 2-6, 9-10, 12, 14, 20, 22, 24, 26, 55, 111, 121, 123, 147, 244, 248, 251, 254, 255, 257, 263, 272, 279, 282, 287, 289, 292, 299, 302, 311, 313, 332, 335, 337, 341, 343, 351, 387, 392, 541.

did.unittitle: Doctor, Doctor!: A Musical Comedy in One Act

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lyrics by John Jakes and Gilbert M. Martin, music by Gilbert M. Martin, book by John Jakes. Music and lyrics copyright by McAfee Music Corporation, New York, 1973. Book copyright by John Jakes, 1973. Based on Le Mdecin malgr lui (The Physician in Spite of Himself) by Molire.

did.unittitle: Oh, Doctor!: A Musical Comedy in Three Acts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Book by Gene Markey, lyrics by Tom Groves, music by Werner Janssen. Hanover, N.H.: The College Bookstore, Dartmouth College, 1919. Performed by the Dartmouth Dramatic Association. Two acts take place in the office of Dr. Brown in New York. Book contains the songs but not the dialogue of the play.

did.unittitle: Oh Doctor!: An Operetta in Two Acts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Book and lyrics by Estelle Merrymon Clark, music by Palmer John Clark. Chicago: The Raymond A. Hoffman Company, c. 1931. Set in a sanitarium and spring near the Mexican Border owned and operated by Dr. Drinkwater.

did.unittitle: Santa Has the Grippe: A Humorous Christmas Cantata

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by Harriet D. Castle Carmichael, music by Ira B. Wilson. Dayton, Ohio: The Lorenz Publishing Co., c. 1907.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Words by J. Blumfield, G. H. Ransome, and F. H., music by C. N. Chadborn. London: St. George's Hospital, 1890s. These are songs by physicians or medical students for their peers. Titles are "Oh, Would I Were a Surgeon," A Song of St. George's," "Back to the Corner Again," "The Veteran Stethoscope," "The Love-Sick Bacillus," "A Lay of the Dissecting Room," "The Lament of the Large White Kidney," "A Bronchitic's Love Song," and "To a Hospital Nurse."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edited by A. L. Nicholson. Melbourne: Medical Students Society, University of Melbourne, 1955. The book contains words of songs only. Some of the songs are medical, and others are popular songs.

did.unittitle: Excerpts from A Collection of New, Standard and Popular Humorous Songs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Selected and edited with New Symphonies & Accompaniments, by J. L. Hatton." London: Boosey & Co., 1890s. The medical songs have been selected by a past owner from the book. They are Mary's Ghost (The Anatomy Song), When a Man's a Little Bit Poorly, Oh! My Tooth It Aches, and Doctor Brown.

did.unittitle: Music publishers taking patent medicine advertisements

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this miscellaneous group, a music publisher sells sheet music that is partly funded by patent medicine advertisements.

did.unittitle: Pine Mountain Merrymakers (M. M. Cole Publishing Co.)

scopecontent.p: This book of songs was copyrighted in 1935 by the M. M. Cole Publishing Co., Chicago. On the back cover is a full page advertisement for Pinex Cough Syrup, prepared by the Pinex Co., Fort Wayne, Indiana.

did.unittitle: Blue Grass Roy (M. M. Cole Publishing Co.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This book of songs was copyrighted in 1935 by the M. M. Cole Publishing Co., Chicago. On the back cover is a full page advertisement for Hamlin's Wizard Oil, which is said to "relieve muscular aches and pains."

did.unittitle: The Maid Who Lives Over the Way (Paladin Publishing Co.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Paladin Publishing Company, Philadelphia, planned to publish a new piece of music each month to be sold for no more than three cents a copy. The inside cover contains a full-page advertisement for Mackie's Sure Dyspepsia Cure, prepared by A. J. H. Mackie, Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two songs published in volume 1 of the periodical or series, Our Musical Guest, published by Bailey, White, & Co., Boston. The song sheets, dated June 1873 and Spring 1874, include advertisements for various medical and other products.

did.unittitle: Song sheets from an unidentified journal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The songs are from an unidentified 19th century publication. With the music are advertisements including those for Mann's Health-Lift, Brooklyn, N.Y., "a thorough Curative System for Ladies and Gentlemen, in ten minutes once a day."
